results.title: Massive Attack: eleven promos
results.brief_description: The pioneering force behind the rise of trip-hop, British band Massive Attack were among the most innovative and influential groups of their generation, renowned for their talents at combining the sounds of hip hop rhythms, soulful melodies, dub grooves and choice samples. Their music is hypnotic, cinematic (in fact their music has featured on numerous soundtracks) and frequently political, addressing the inequities of society and the perilous state of mankind. This disc features eleven film clips, ranging from 1990-98, and includes: Daydreaming (Dir: Billie Walsh, 1990) ; Unfinished sympathy (Dir: Billie Walsh, 1991) ; Safe from harm (Dir: Billie Walsh, 1991) ; Be thankful for what you’ve got (Dir: Billie Walsh, 1992) ; Sly (Dir: Stephane Sednaoui, 1994) ; Protection (Dir: Michel Gondry, 1995) ; Karmacoma (Dir: Jonathan Glazer, 1995) ; Risingson (Dir: Walter Stern, 1997) ; Teardrop (Dir: Billie Walsh, 1990) ; Angel (Dir: Walter Stern, 1998) ; Inertia Creeps (Dir: Wiz, 1998). The clips range in technique, some, like “Inertia Creeps”, are stylish and conceptual, others such as “Safe from harm” and “Unfinished sympathy” are notable for their location (a disused tower block, East London and Peico Avenue, Los Angeles respectively), simple in execution, and succeed in commenting on the social milieu in which they are set.

results.title: Puberty blues [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Margaret Kelly, Joan Long and Limelight Productions
results.brief_description: Unusually, the focus here is on the sexual and social rites of passage of two teenage girls in a male-dominated world. Debbie and Sue are accepted into the Greenhills’ gang, an elite group occupying a particular stretch of Cronulla beach. As surfie groupies Debbie and Sue are required to submit to male whims. Although the girls are proposed as subjects the film maintains a humorously ironic distance from the awfulness of the scene, particularly through the use of narration. The boys, collectively dominant, are individually consigned to the margins. Debbie and Sue are the real mates who ultimately break out of the confines of male-imposed rules. Cast includes: Nell Schofield, Jad Capelja, Geoff Rhoe, Tony Hughes. Based on the book by Kathy Lette and Gabrielle Carey.

results.title: Josie and the pussycats [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Deborah Kaplan, Harry Elfont, Marc Platt, Chuck Grimes, Tracey E. Edmonds, Tony De Rosa-Grund, Riverdale Productions, Universal Pictures and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Based on the Archie comic book series, this teen flick is an exuberant adaptation of the characters of Josie, Valerie and Melody who form a rock group and are catapulted to stardom overnight after being discovered by a talent scout. Unbeknownst to the girls however, the label they have signed with, MegaRecords, run by Fiona (Parker Posey, revelling in the role of arch-villainess), insert subaural messages into the music that brainwashes teenagers into buying an array of products, from shoes to deodorant. When the label pushes Josie as the main artist, diminishing the roles of Val and Mel, the girls’ friendship is threatened. This film successfully satirises teenage marketing, consumerism, product placement, all-boy bands, manufactured pop and teen movies but undermines its credibility by gratifying the teen wish-fulfillment fantasy. The gaudy palette is utilised to great effect from the costumes of the band to the ever-changing sets; and the self-reflexive pop references flow thick and fast throughout the script that oscillates between all-knowing cleverness and straight up pandering to mainstream culture. Ultimately the film cannot decide which side of the fence it sits on but remains an amusing, fun distraction. Cast includes Rachael Leigh Cook, Tara Reid, Rosario Dawson, Alan Cumming and Gabriel Mann.

results.title: The Cat's meow [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Bogdanovich, Julie Baines, Dieter Meyer, Carol Lewis, Kim Bieber, Bieber + Lewis, Dan Films, CP Medien and Lions Gate Films
results.brief_description: Based on an old Hollywood rumour, “The Cat’s meow” is about William Randolph Hearst, the media magnate infamous in the 1920s for his power and wealth. In this story, “the whisper told most often” as one character puts it, the year is 1924 and Hearst’s private yacht is headed for San Diego, with a dozen guests, a mix of Hollywood power players and ambitious types, aboard. Amid the high profile travellers are Charlie Chaplin, gossip columnist Louella Parsons, actress, and Hearst’s long-term mistress, Marion Davies pioneering film producer and director Thomas Ince and acerbic novelist Elinor Glyn. As the ship sails, the intricate, and at times intimate, relationships between the players are placed under pressure by shifting power plays and the separate agendas of each character. Due to his legendary paranoia, Hearst has placed ‘bugs’ throughout the boat, enabling him to scrutinise, in particular, the relationship of Chaplin and Davies. The most interesting aspect of the film watching the larger than life Chaplin (deftly played by British comedian Eddie Izzard), operate not as a great artist, but as simply a man on the make. Hearst, depicted as a jealous and curmudgeonly buffoon, eavesdropping on his guests and girlfriend, trusting no one, is far more one-dimensional. Also of note is Kirsten Dunst who gives an infectiously joyous portrayal of Davies, a much-maligned comedian of her times. “The Cat’s meow” struggles as a murder mystery, but works well as a prism of 1920s Hollywood when the allure of stars like Chaplin was at a pinnacle, fed by an adoring public.

results.title: The Disorderly orderly
results.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin, Paul Jones and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In his eighth, and final, collaboration with director Frank Tashlin, Jerry Lewis plays Jerome Littlefield, a nurse in a sanatorium whose manic and clumsy antics manage to upset patients and staff alike. Lewis is given free reign here to display his usual brand of silly, goofy and slapstick physical humour. Typically, although Jerome is a sympathetic attendant, he effortlessly manages to derail those he cares for. In one hilarious scene a hypochondriac patient relays her many maladies as Lewis displays her symptoms. Another highlight is a quite mad chase through hilly streets, with an ambulance in pursuit of a freewheeling stretcher (with a stunned patient aboard), ending in a catastrophic encounter with numerous supermarket trolleys. As this comedy is set in a hospital, some salient points are made about systemic corruption and profit margins that increase with a simultaneous decline in care. But quite expectedly, the darker tones of the film are marginalised in favour of comedic set-pieces, consistent with Lewis’ other work, and highlights his talent for physical idiocy and facial expressiveness. Also stars Glenda Farrell, Everett Sloane, Karen Sharpe and Kathleen Freeman.

results.title: Artists and models
results.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin, Hal B. Wallis and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In this satirical slapstick comedy Dean Martin plays Rick Todd, a fledging painter who has relocated to New York in search of acclaim. Eugene, Rick’s best friend and housemate also has ambitions, as a children’s writer, but his clumsy antics continuously lose them menial jobs that they land. Despite their misfortunes the impoverished pair dream of greater things, such as food, girls, money and fame. Along the way, the friends woo their luscious neighbours, comic book artist Abigail (Dorothy Malone) and her model, Bessie (Shirley MacLaine). When Abigail resigns after being asked to beef up her storylines with more blood and gore, Rick takes her job, using Eugene’s ecstatic and vivid dreams as material. Eugene dreams up the secret formula for rocket fuel, and enemy agents are soon on his tail. Several musical interludes pepper the film that is alight with sight gags, physical and madcap humour, and despite its largely formulaic approach, is one of the finest Lewis and Martin comedies made as a duo.

results.title: The Bonfire of the vanities
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description:
Brian De Palma’s adaptation of Tom Wolfe’s tome to political corruption and greed in New York City was an unmitigated disaster for the filmmaker and all involved. Playing against type, Tom Hanks was cast as Sherman McCoy, a slick Wall Street trader, who immersed in the high-pressure world of stocks and bonds, enjoys reaping the financial rewards of his job. But Sherman’s Achilles heel is his extramarital affair with Maria Ruskin, a buxom Southern belle, who amuses Sherman with her uneducated speech, but reveals a ruthless streak when she runs over a black teenager in Harlem and Sherman is sent to trial. It is drunken reporter Peter Fallow who uncovers the scandal, despite misgivings about the motivations of the players who help him. Unfortunately, encapsulating the many strains of Wolfe’s novel proved too complex for the script, which leaves many characters as ciphers and fails to flesh out the motivations of the central players. Nevertheless, within the context of the extravagant, tasteless excesses of the 1980s, the film serves as an intriguing tableau of corruptibility, vice, greed and human foibles.
Cast includes: Tom Hanks, Bruce Willis, Melanie Griffith, Kim Cattrall, Morgan Freeman, F. Murray Abraham

results.title: Fingers
results.creator_credit: James Toback, George Barrie and Brut Films
results.brief_description: A talented pianist is placed under enormous mental strain, caught between a rarefied world and the sadistic, violent milieu of the mafia. Harvey Keitel plays Jimmy Angelelli, a man who yearns for perfection as a performer but at the same time is pressurised by his abusive father to become involved in the family business of organised crime. Unfortunately Jimmy has an incendiary temper, which makes him ill suited for the work, and when it comes to his anger and frustration, he is without boundaries. Cruising the grimy New York streets with his noisy boom box, playing an incessant round of pop hits, Jimmy is dangerously unhinged and his mental state and grasp on reality, slowly erodes. James Toback’s (Two girls and a guy, Black and white) debut feature is a fascinating view of a man at war with himself and features a stunning lead performance by Keitel. Like Scorsese’s early work (such as Who’s That Knocking at My Door? and Mean Streets) Toback utilises the New York setting to explore one man’s mental deterioration, a theme echoed two years earlier in “Taxi Driver”. Cast also includes Tisa Farrow, Jim Brown and Michael Vincente Gazzo.

Unfortunately Jimmy has an incendiary temper, which makes him ill suited for the work, and when it comes to his anger and frustration, he is without boundaries. Cruising the grimy New York streets with his noisy boom box, playing an incessant round of pop hits, Jimmy is dangerously unhinged and his mental state and grasp on reality, slowly erodes. James Toback’s (Two girls and a guy, Black and white) debut feature is a fascinating view of a man at war with himself and features a stunning lead performance by Keitel. Like Scorsese’s early work (such as Who’s That Knocking at My Door? and Mean Streets) Toback utilises the New York setting to explore one man’s mental deterioration, a theme echoed two years earlier in “Taxi Driver”. Cast also includes Tisa Farrow, Jim Brown and Michael Vincente Gazzo.
description_for_label: A talented pianist is placed under enormous mental strain, caught between a rarefied world and the sadistic, violent milieu of the mafia. Harvey Keitel plays Jimmy Angelelli, a man who yearns for perfection as a performer but at the same time is pressurised by his abusive father to become involved in the family business of organised crime. Unfortunately Jimmy has an incendiary temper, which makes him ill suited for the work, and when it comes to his anger and frustration, he is without boundaries. Cruising the grimy New York streets with his noisy boom box, playing an incessant round of pop hits, Jimmy is dangerously unhinged and his mental state and grasp on reality, slowly erodes. James Toback’s (Two girls and a guy, Black and white) debut feature is a fascinating view of a man at war with himself and features a stunning lead performance by Keitel. Like Scorsese’s early work (such as Who’s That Knocking at My Door? and Mean Streets) Toback utilises the New York setting to explore one man’s mental deterioration, a theme echoed two years earlier in “Taxi Driver”. Cast also includes Tisa Farrow, Jim Brown and Michael Vincente Gazzo.

results.title: Harry Potter and the chamber of secrets
results.creator_credit: Chris Columbus, David Heyman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The second instalment in the Harry Potter series returns to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, in what is arguably a stronger film than its predecessor, despite belief that the novel on which the film is based, is the weakest in the series. An enchanting musical score and solid animation are supported by strong performances of young actors Daniel Radcliff, Emma Watson and Rupert Grint, who reprise their roles as Harry, Hermione and Ron. Between dealing with cryptic house-elves, flying cars, Quidditch, and attempting to keep one step ahead of the nasty Slytherins, who has time to study? However, when muggle-born students are being attacked, it is once again up to Harry and his friends to save the day. The all-star British cast includes Jason Isaacs as the malicious Lucius Malfoy and Kenneth Branagh as pompous professor Gilderoy Lockhart who join Richard Harris, in one of his final roles, Maggie Smith, Alan Rickman, Robbie Coltrane, John Cleese, Fiona Shaw, Zoe Wanamaker, Julie Walters, John Hurt, Ian Hart, Richard Griffiths and Warwick Davis.

results.title: Before sunrise
results.creator_credit: Richard Linklater, Anne Walker-McBay, F I L M H A U S, Detour Filmproduction and Castle Rock Entertainment
results.brief_description: This romantic comedy, set in Vienna, is essentially a two-hander with a simple but effective set-up. Jesse (Ethan Hawke) is an American tourist who, travelling on the Budapest to Vienna train, meets French grad student, Celine. When Jesse reveals he plans to roam Vienna, awaiting his morning flight back to the US, Celine spontaneously decides to spend the night with him walking and talking, discovering the city and each other. Linklater’s romantic comedy works exceptionally well - his camera sits intimately and comfortably with his protagonists as they converse about family, ambition, death, life, love and sex. The deft and funny script explores the possibilities of two people forming an attraction over the course of a fortuitous day, without stooping to typical rom-com tropes that tend to mar the genre. Linklater (Dazed and confused, Slacker, SubUrbia, Waking life, Tape), who for a time specialised in films that addressed the concerns of Generation X, presents a brief encounter that is talky, urbane, wistful, understated, reflective, poignant and romantic.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Linklater, Anne Walker-McBay, F I L M H A U S, Detour Filmproduction and Castle Rock Entertainment
